author: meyerc13
title: smart Little Car
review:
I found this set tonight for $4.99US at the local Toys R Us store and picked it up.  My wife looked at it after my son and I put it together and instantly named the real life vehicle that obviously served as the inspiration for this car, so I think LEGO hit a home run in the design department.  The mini-fig is also nice, with a double sided torso displaying the pocket and hood from his hoodie.

I almost rated this lower, mostly based on the price.  If you compare the finished vehicle to the 7236 police car, which typically sells for only about $1 more, it just seems so small.  I like 7236 because it has good parts for making your own vehicles.  It doesn't seem like this set could possibly have the same valuable pieces in such a small package.  However, looking at the pieces you do get, you get a windshield, mudguards, a hood/roof piece, and doors.  Yes, doors!  These are great pieces for building your own creations.  The only bad thing is that you get one black mudguard and one white mudguard, so pick up two of these sets if you plan to make your own creations using that part.

Don't let the small size fool you, this is a great little car.  For not much more than an impulse mini-fig set, you get a mini-fig with a car.  Yes, the car is small, but when you compare it to the real life inspiration it is supposed to be small.  Pick these up when you spot them, but grab a few because for the price you'll get some great parts that are very useful.

author: LegoCoastalPatrol
title: City Car…
review:
I ordered this from Lego.com on the 30.12.09 and it arrived today (05.01.10).   As soon as I saw this set in the previews I knew that it would soon be joining my collection, and I am really glad that it has.

This is one of the latest cars from the City range which I have bought recently, and compared to the supplied minifig and the other cars which have been released recently, this car is very small and typical of the many small ‘city cars’ which are currently on the market.   It looks similar to a Smart Car, but it could be representative of the Toyota IQ.  One thing is for certain, Lego seem to have got it just right with this set.   The car is presented in a clean black and white colour scheme.   The front area features a white bumper, number plate holder (but no number plate), small round headlights and a grille.   There is no bonnet, but a slanted windscreen adds to the sporty feel of the car.   Two white doors are provided to gain access along with a removable roof.   A high visibility red ‘stop’ lamp is incorporated into the roof panel.   The gradual slope of the rear quarter meets the rear wheels but no bumper is provided.   There is a small luggage area provided at the rear of the car for the attaché case (provided).   The minifig wears a trendy haircut, hooded top and green trousers.   Could he be a student?   I could imagine him parking on my university campus!

Well, my first set of 2010, and an excellent, excellent choice.   Great price and a great ‘fresh’ set.

Well done Lego!

author: quickbuild1234
title: Review: Small Car
review:
Building Experience: Nothing amazing here--but what can be said about 43 pieces? It was a quick two minutes to snap them together into a cute little smart car.

Parts: Nothing major from the small amount of pieces--a window, a curved roof, some tires, and a nice briefcase. There are also some door pieces and a steering wheel that might come in handy.

Minifigures: The single figure is slightly more than generic; Mutt Williams style hair and face, yellow instead of flesh; a nice blue and white sweatshirt that isn't seen often, making it a very nice addition, and some simple green pants.

Playability: Whether it's the center of attention, or in the background, this small car is versatile enough to be used for about anything--a passing vehicle, a chase, whatever you can come up with. The roof comes off well, there's a nice spot for the briefcase in back, and the teenager figure fits into the car perfectly.

Value for Money: It's completely worth it--5 bucks, 43 pieces, and a versatile little vehicle and minifigure sure to come in handy in any street setting.

5/5

review:
With a glut of semis, haulers and transporters over the past couple of years, everyday automobiles seem to come up short in the current LEGO line up. It's nice to have something current and trendy, but the bland white and black color scheme completely misses a signature aspect of the Smart car (I'm not even sure the real Smart car is available in white). This model needs color! We already have the recent LEGO City Camper 7639, which is also white. The 3177 car begs for lime green or rich blue.

Overall rating:
It's cute. This model accurately depicts the ultra small car market with the exception of color.

Building experience:
Easy. Some of the parts didn't have a good fit. See parts.

Parts:
I don't recall exactly which bricks they were, but one of the bricks on the front end of car had some minor warp to it, which made the model look a little less attractive. I think I was able to trade out or reverse the part to resolve this.

Playability:
Space efficient. This car fits nicely in the garage of the 4956 house. But the house is white and so is the car. Too much white.

There is an issue with the driver not fitting in the car. This can be resolved by removing the rear brake light temporarily. Not an ideal solution, but it works. Seems to be durable.

Value for money:
An affordable way to add a few more every LEGO cars to your set.

Areas for improvement:
The round front headlights should probably be square. There is only a single center rear brake light. I'd like to see additional tail/brake lights. As mentioned previously the high contrast white and black color scheme is rather stark and could be confused as a police car or an ambulance. A color scheme that matches the spirit of the car would be great.

My recommendation is that LEGO should release a kit with two identical 3177 cars with mix and match colors schemes, perhaps pink/white and lime green/black, and male and female drivers.

author: Odeinoichus
title: LEGO City Smart Car
review:
Set #3177 Small Car: In real life you don't see many people driving these cars, but they do occassionally appear on the road. So it makes sense that LEGO would make one available in their LEGO City for you to add to your vehicle menagerie.

 

The model is compact, it uses black and white pieces mostly to make a little Smart Car for the LEGO Citizen to drive. The model is fast and simple to build, but it does have a few odd choices in the design. The rear of the vheicle is open to the air (not good for winter driving in snowy climes.), understandably this is done so that you can slip the suitcase in and out easily, but it does make for a car that isn't completely closed off from the elements. It also doesn't have door windows (although I don't know any LEGO Automobiles that actually do have door windows.), and the Mini-Figure is a bit tricky to get into the car and seal the roof back shut. Mostly because of the hair piece, I finally figured out which angle to leave the torso at in order to close the roof back over him so he can sit and drive and not get rained on.

 

The Mini-Figure himself is fun looking, he comes with a double sided torso that resembles a sweatshirt with hoody, the print is very nice and it makes me wish that LEGO had given him a hat piece that made it look like he was actually wearing the hoody as well as the hair piece. He also comes with a suitcase. I'm not sure if he's on a trip or he's going to the office on casual Friday with his briefcase full of paperwork... Either way he's a great addition to LEGO City.

 

Overall I'd have to say that buying this set is something all fans of LEGO City should do, it's cheap and a fun little car to put next to your larger vehicles. Now if LEGO would just make a new version available in alternate colors, perhaps a rich dark green and blue combo for the next version. You can't go wrong with the price either, but steer clear of picking this up at TRU in Canada, they've bumped the price up confusingly so from 6.99$ to 7.99$ meaning you're paying 2$ more after taxes.

author: coldcomfort
title: 3177 Small Car - Help your Lego City "go green" with this new Smart Car.
review:
First of all, I have to point out that my ratings of sets are subjective based on what I believe the overall intent of the set to be. For example, my expectations of $100 USD+ major sets are much higher and more detailed than my expectations for middle price point and inexpensive impulse sets. When I decided to pick up this set I expected a cool new minifigure and a cool new car. Bearing those criteria in mind, this kit is everything I wanted from it.

Pros

  • The minifigure is attractive and a civilian. This is important to me because as a buyer of sets in retail stores I have wound up with far more police officers, firefighters and construction workers than regular folk.
  • The car is a dead ringer for a Smart Car - adding elements of authenticity, modernity and environmental consciousness to the City theme. It also has the same color scheme as the vehicles driven by those Geek Squad tech support folks here in the states, so if you'd like you could find a decal and have a real world brand in your City.
  • The car is actually quite a bit more detailed than I initially thought it would be. It has working doors, a roof and even a storage compartment for the driver's briefcase. I was kind of impressed with this because oftentimes the smaller vehicles included in the larger more expensive sets do not have these features. For example consider the little red car included in the 7288 Mobile Police Unit set. While it has working doors, it lacks both a roof and any storage area.
  • This set is a strong value. Having purchased mine via the internet I paid a bit more than those of you that may have the opportunity to buy it locally might, but even with the extra dollar or so for shipping I think it's well worth the money.
  • What could possibly be more playable than a little car?

Cons

Since this set delivers exactly what I expected from it and does so at a price I feel is better than reasonable I can't think of a single bad thing to say about it. It's inexpensive, smartly designed and fun. If you enjoy the City theme, this is a vehicle you'll likely want to include in your motor pool.

The Good:

 1) Opening doors are a wonderful feature and this tiny set has a pair of them. It adds that tiny bit of playability.

2) The design of the vehicle also resembles a Smart car from yesteryears as already pointed out by several reviewers. But perhaps what makes this set really cheerful is the fact that the pieces used are fairly conventional and can be swapped out with other colours. This gives rise to endless customization possibilities.

3) This set can be considered an army builder which can be used to populate your growing Lego City scene on display. Imagine a city filled with these tiny wonders in various colors or even multicolored versions. In fact, I even customized mine to have spoilers inspired by Pikes Peak racers. The short video on this can be found in the video reviews section. The best part is the set retailed at a very reasonable price back when it was launched.

4) One youthful looking minifigure is also included. He wears a hoodie which is in tune with his youthful character although the accompanying briefcase feels out of place.

The Bad:

Conventional pieces used and very fast build.

The verdict:

The set has good smiles per buck value and fulfills it's purpose either on it's own or as an addition to your Lego scene. As the latter quoted ad mentions, 'You Don't Need A Big One To Be Happy'.

author: CamberbrickGreen
title: Mini-Figure's Mini-Vehicle
review:
This small car represents a city or smart car very well, ignoring the usual minifigure scale problems of one figure to one vehicle (6 stud wide vehicles still only cater for one minifig despite potential build techniques for more).

Minifigures:
  • Green trousers/ white and blue hoodie/ light green t-shirt print/ dark brown hair. Brown leather briefcase.
The green trousers seem rather unusual and not subtle enough for combats, otherwise jeans would seem better. A trendy city type, he could almost be imagined as self employed or in the media or graphics business?!

Micro Machine
The car build is a very straight forward small chassis and component add on but with some modern bricks and good use of interesting pieces to make the design, not anything out of what is obvious in the picture. OK thats a little lazy, check out the smooth tyres, angled front plate and the fact the car is barely any longer than just the small chassis, quite impressive! That tinted window is pretty snazzy also.

Kids will love this as a discreet car and character to hide in their towns and go anywhere with due to its diminutive shape that fits as happily in small hands as a large diecast car. Smaller sets often get overly high prices on them and this one has crept up 50p over the space of one year. Worth getting as cheap as you can find it or use shopper reward points.

If you love vehicles in Lego then its possibly collectable as the only set so far of this type of car. Because there have been frequent and equally small vehicles, usually open top, this is actually its most remarkable point in that it is as tiny a car as has yet been made to hold a minifigure so it scores for this uniqueness.

That little eco-driver barely fits inside his economical and space friendly modern automobile. The roof only just fits when he is tilted slightly in his seat but this adds to the fun 'how small can you go?' encapsulation concept. His suitcase fits in the back and it would have been nice to get a simple transparent brick for a back window as the car is rather ventilated.

Tin Can On Wheels
A pleasant small set that many people will end up with, the smart car is indeed smart in its accurate black and white. To balance size across the Lego vehicle sets lets hope we see more 6-10 stud wide vans, coaches and trucks to help 'dwarf' the smallness.

author: Harmonious_Building
title: Micro machine.
review:
Ah yes, the Small Car. It's a car, and it's small, and close to 80 people have decided to chime in with an opinion stating as such. If there is a non-licensed set with more reviews than this one, I don't know what it is. 

I'm sure that part of the reason why this set has so many reviews is that there is really no reason to not own this set as long as you have the most rudimentary of City collections at your disposal. It's a full vehicle and a cool Minifig for $5, and it's really hard to get any better than that (except perhaps for BBQ Stand (8398), another exceptionally cool City impulse set). All the details for a car are packed tightly into a surprisingly intricate design that is sure to offend Americans who subscribe to the philosophy that a car is only as good as its approximation to an armoured vehicle. 

One small annoyance with this set, however, is the transparent red piece that sits just beneath the canopy. If placed so as advised by the directions, the Minifig has to lean really far forward in order to be able to sit squarely inside the vehicle, which may conjure up certain images of Korean grandmothers that probably ought not to be behind the wheel of a thousand pound machine of death. Also, a second white L-shaped piece allows the Minifig's briefcase to fit much more snugly in the car. This design was used at least once - in the money transport truck in Bank & Money Transfer (3661), so why it was not recycled in such a natural location is a bit baffling. 

It has probably cost you more than $5 already to sit here reading this review, so enough with the philosophical agonising: get this set. It's fun, it's cheap, it's small, and it's a car. There, maybe now this will be the last review, though probably not.

author: bricksan
title: 3177 Small Car
review:
After doing 5 straight classic Pirate reviews, I thought it would be worth reviewing other sets I own. So I have now switched to the City theme. This combined with the Modulars is currently my favourite theme due to my City Project. The set I have selected to review first is the one of the smallest boxed sets you can have.

Obviously there are the smaller polybag sets but there is something quirky with this set that made me do an impulse by from Asada Living. The set cost me £3.49 and is still on general sale, ranging from anything from £3.99 on shop@home to £3.79 in stores such as ASDA and Tesco.

Introduction


The set was released in December 2009 and is a 4 stud wide car. In the City theme you either get 4 stud vehicles or 6 stud vehicles . I usually prefer the large 6 stud ones as they are more detailed. However this car reminds me of the Smart Car you find in most City centers in the UK. 

The set is pocket money purchase I would assume these days. I know most kids get a lot more pocket money then I did and for £3.99 you get 43 pieces for your money, the minifigure in this look only appears in this set, however the torso has been used on more than one occasion, appearing in various sets, such as the LEGO Marina last year. I would have given the minifigure a suit and it would have been better suited to the car.
The set comes in a small box, unlike the classic sets you no longer get other ideas on the back which is a shame, on most large City sets you get a comic. This is just set details, copyright writing etc. The instructions comes in a small A6 booklet, that is layed out in a horizontal format. The cover is the car and minifig carrying a briefcase.  At the back is  two  City layouts, one with the fire brigade and one with the airport. Also these days you also get a parts list at the back as well.

The Build


The build is split into 15 stages, with each stage consisting of adding 2 or more elements to the build. At the start you get the car frame that has been around for a long time, heck I remember having a two white ones for an old LEGO Town Race track, the set was  the Motor Speedway from 1987, the element has been used in 79 different sets dating back to the early 80's. Yet it is still a decent element for build small cars.

Stages 2-4 consists of  adding the wheel archers and sides of the car. In  stage 5 you add the steering wheel, mounted to two green 1×2 plates, why green though? . Steps 7 though to 9 is spent building the front of  the car. It is worth mentioning it is one of the few modern cars not to have a sticker number plate, which is a real shame. The next 4 stages is spent adding the windscreen and black supports for the roof, as well as the black roof. I like how the back light of the car is part of the roof. The last stage is adding the wheels and minifigure.

Final Thoughts


Overall it is not a hard built, the instructions are simple to follow with nothing hard about the build at all. In truth  it is not an exciting build and is one that most in the targeted age range would find easy to assemble. However I do like it for a small set and if anything it adds another car to a City layout for next to nothing, it works out about 9p a piece which is not bad at all.

Although unless you are a City fan I can’t see it appealing to most AFOL’s but if you are then at less then £4 get one and fill out your City.

author: The_Brick_Guy_87
title: Looks good except for the rear
review:
This appears to be the most owned set of 2010. Even many non-City fans appear to have it. The more popular it is, the more loved it seems to be. Personally, I think it is a bit overrated. Read the review to know why.

Parts

43 pieces are included in this set. There aren't any rare parts here, except for perhaps the small car base. The main colors here are white and black as they make up the car. Not a bad parts selection.

Build

Takes about 3-4 minutes. No special building techniques here.

The completed model

Once built, you have a minifig and a car.

The minifig appears to be a young student. He has green pants, a white sweater with a hoodie and a wallet, dark brown messy hair and a smile on his face. He also has a brown suitcase. Nothing special but he is a nice civilian for a city.

The car appears to be a mimicry of the Smart Fortwo or the Toyota IQ/Aston Martin Cygnet. It has a white and black color scheme. It has white doors. On the front there are round headlights, a dark grey grille and a 1x2 flat tile serving as a license plate holder, although there is no actual license plate. All good for now.

The rear, however, seems to have been left unfinished by the designer. There is no rear window. The suitcase falls off its storage place easily. The 1x2 transparent red tile does not work well as a brake light IMO. I know this can be fixed by modifying the set, but still!

Another flaw is that the minifig is a little bit hard to put because there is little space inside the car and the roof has the transparent tile underneath it so the minifig has to be in a specific position so you can put the roof back on its place.

Overall opinion

This is a nice little set for a city. It plays well with other sets, but you can't play much with it on its own. That, along with the aforementioned 2 flaws lower the rating to a 4. Thanks for reading, and if you find this review unhelpful, please contact me to give me some feedback to write better reviews. Goodbye!
